Reviews.Title: Many DON'T HAVE SAMSUNG PANELS - HUGE quality difference
Reviews.Author: HopefullyThoughtful
Reviews.Content: Many of these TVs don't have a Samsung panel (the screen/the part that has/makes the image!)! I cannot believe this has not been mentioned. It makes a SUBSTANTIAL difference, because some panels they use should be in TV's that cost $100 less.[...]Can you imagine buying a car because you know its manufacturer uses great, reliable engines, only to find out that they use completely different engines without telling you, all of which are of lower quality? Samsung does this with their TVs, and some of them don't EVER have Samsung panels (e.g., the 37" model will NEVER have a Samsung panel because they don't make 37" panels). Samsung uses 4 different panel types from four different manufacturers - each with a substantially different technology.You can tell which panel YOUR TV has by the "Version" on the sticker outside of the box. There's also a sticker on the back of the TV; the "Version" code is below the Model number and above the S/N. BTW, reviews can't be interpreted without the four-digit Version code because they are quite simply different TV's. Here's how to interpret them:("x" means a number, probably from 1-4, that represents the version of that panel - higher means newer but not always better).TH0x or TS0x: Samsung S-PVA panel (possibly just a PVA, if you're less lucky): This is what you thought you were buying. Best color, best black, best viewing angles.HS0x: Sharp ASV panel: Lower contrast ratio, more narrow viewing angle. I read HS02 in particular has terrible ghosting.A_0X: AOU A-MVA panel: Even lower contrast ratio.CH0x or CM0x or CS0x: Chimea S-MVA panel: You lost the lottery. Markedly worse in every way - way worse viewing angle, color reproduction, etc. Just a terrible rip-off.Mine, from Amazon, is an HS03, so a Sharp panel. I will be testing it tomorrow (DVD and watching football - no Blu-ray). There is a decent chance I return it, because it is not a Samsung. Also? Sony and Panasonic do much less "panel lottery" and are vowing to stop entirely. LG does not do a panel lottery. Samsung has absolutely no plans to stop, and they only use "standards" that won't reveal a difference between the different panels.I will update after doing more testing. I just simply could not believe that this was not mentioned. Nothing like finding out you paid $500 (40" model) for a $400 TV when that extra $100 could have been used for sound, Blu-Ray, etc.**Other reviewers, please, update your reviews to give your version code!**More reading:[...]UPDATED 10/24/12: Added info on how to find version number without the box.

Reviews.Title: Great TV after a lot of tweaking
Reviews.Author: Gordon "PS3/PC Gamer!"
Reviews.Content: If you're anything like me you see that this TV is labeled as LED; then you look at the picture and see a lot of fat for the usual Samsung LED depth. Make no mistake this is an LED TV.  I got this for my bedroom to replace my 23 inch Samsung Syncmaster. I use this TV mostly for 1080 mp4 movies and blurays (I download what I want to watch instead of waiting for it on cable), and my Xbox and PS3.I learned 2 things about the TV right off the bat. If you have Comcast, you cannot fully customize the TV's picture. An essential feature called HDMI black levels actually looks much better when its set to low. I have 2 different Comcast HD boxes and since neither of them broadcast at 1080, this feature is locked out. Long story short, Comcast had me thinking I purchased my first dud from Samsung. Seriously, the colors look washed out and none of the channels really had that crisp clear picture I was hoping for. If you plan to use this solely for Comcast, I can't really recommend it. In fact, I've always found blu ray quality to be so much better than cable that I've stopped using cable for anything but football and cartoons. Movies MUST be in my PS3's blu ray player or my own 1080p files.The second thing I learned about is what the depth is for. Samsung didn't advertise this (or maybe its just my TV), but I have absolutely NO BACKLIGHT BLEED. When Black Ops goes to the loading screen on my Xbox, it gets so dark that I think the TV is off! The only indication that it is on is the Black Ops logo in the corner spinning. There isn't even the SLIGHTEST inkling of white anywhere! I'm not exaggerating. The obvious second reason why this TV is fat for an LED is that Samsung made an effort to improve the sound. When I turn on the HD surround coupled with the movie option, there is much more bass than I thought it would be. THe explosions in my games and the soundtracks in movies sound vastly better than I thought they would. Granted, I am not the type to go out and spend 600 on some Bose speakers, but the sound is NOT a con for me this time around.NOW ON TO THE PICTUREAs I said, I was not exactly thrilled with the picture RIGHT off the bat. It looked like my old 23 inch Syncmaster, just a lot bigger. Let me tell you, this is not one of those TV's that look great right out of the box. You have to toy around with the settings a bit to get the optimal picture. I wanted sharpness coupled with colors that pop like crazy.....and I got it. Dynamic is the brightest setting, but I coupled this with the HDMI black levels set to low (option not available for Comcast cable box) and voila, moving photographs! I'm not a pro but this is my setup:Mode: DynamicBacklight: 18Contrast: 85Brightness: 50Sharpness: 80Color: 70TInt: G/R 50/50Standard color tone with screen fit in the additional options, with HDMI black level set to low.My games and blurays look AMAZING. The picture is easily better than my mom's 46 inch Samsung up front. REMEMBER that some of the good options are cut off from Comcast and the use of component cables. In games, I do have to up the brightness or gamma a little, but it ends up looking BRILLIANT. I am going through my entire library of games and they feel like entirely new experiences! There is a 32 inch 720p option as well, but I just was not comfortable with 720p max. The new game consoles are gojng to have native 1080 so that's what I wanted. BTW did I mention I'm a big gamer?THE CONSWell I saw this TV up on Amazon before it was on Samsung's website. Yeah, WOW. Sometimes I wanted to see the TVs specs from Samsung directly before I made my buy. Make no mistake this is NOT a 120 HZ tv although it is labeled as one. I have no idea what clearmotion 120 is, but it makes my TV much darker. The feature is entirely useless and does nothing to the picture or add the "soap opera" effect like I had hoped (it looks great for games).WITH A COMCAST CABLE BOX I could see no difference between HDMI and component. I kept switching back and fourth, but since the max output is 1080i, there were no differences in picture.The last iteration of this TV had 4 HDMIs. What happened?VERDICTWith a lot of tweaking, I got the picture to look beautiful. I will use my Comcast box sparingly, but I might move to FIOS if the support full 1080. Watching movies on my PS3 and playing games on my Xbox stopped me from returning the TV. I will not be surprised if this set gets bad reviews from Comcast users (even though Its not Samsung's fault). I'm a "videophile" and this passed my personal test with vibrant colors.FEEL FREE TO ASK ME ANYTHING!

Reviews.Title: Fantastic TV (after a few minor adjustments)
Reviews.Author: bareyb
Reviews.Content: If you are looking for the best picture quality for the buck, you have found it. Samsung put the money where it matters most and if you don't care about 3D or a bunch of inputs this is a great buy. This is the hands down winner for a Back Lit LED TV at this price point.Pros:Great Picture quality (with a few adjustments, see below)Really good Sound Quality. Better than most.Matte Screen (not Glossy), so low reflections in bright roomsFull Array LED backlighting (versus "Edge lit" Fluorescent as most LCD's have)Great styling. The angled corners on the bottom, the large base and thin bezel all come together to give it a sophisticated look.Cons:Stock picture settings. Picture is a bit soft and washed out with the stock configuration. You need to adjust the settings to get it to really shine to it's full potential.I used the Display Mate DVD to professionally calibrate the screen and I used those settings as a starting point. My personal preference is for a bit more "pop" and a sharper picture and I think I've come up with the ideal settings for this particular TV.  I listed all the "Default" settings, the "Display Mate Calibration DVD" Settings, and my Personal Settings below. Hope that helps you find the settings that work best for you.Default Settings:Mode: StandardBacklight 18Contrast 95Brightness 45Sharpness  20Color  50Tint: G/R 50/50******************************************Calibrated with "Display Mate"  DVD:Mode: DynamicBacklight 20Contrast 100Brightness 45Sharpness  0Color  41Tint: G/R 50/50****************************************My Settings:Mode: DynamicBacklight 18Contrast 98Brightness 45Sharpness  60Color  50Tint: G/R 50/50* Color Tone "Standard" and "Screen Fit" in Picture Options. LED "Motion Plus" option: OFF

Reviews.Title: Great, solid TV.
Reviews.Author: J. Karels
Reviews.Content: I received this TV yesterday to add a TV for our bedroom.  I own another Samsung LCD so I knew I would be happy with this one.Since it was going into the bedroom, it didn't need to be fancy or have all the bells and whistles.  I figure I'll add a Roku or Apple TV to it and be all set.While this TV is LED, it's not as thin as you're used to seeing.  I believe it's just over three inches thick in the rear, but it has a very thin bezel up front.  It has minimal connections in back, but all I'll ever use is HDMI, so that doesn't concern me.  Picture quality out-of-the-box is great and became even nicer with a little tweaking.  That's usually the first thing I do is try to eyeball calibrate it at first.  It's too new to have any good calibration settings posted on the net; I figure I'll use last year's 'D' model as a guideline and wait until settings are posted.  I did not notice any flash-lighting with this model -- something that plagued last year's 'D' lineup.  I have yet to play any 1080p material on this to really test it (only watched a few minutes of HDTV ((720p)) broadcasts), so I'll update this post when I do.Note this year's 'EH' line is Samsung's basic model lineup, with the 'ES' being the more expensive, feature-laden models.  This is a great set if you want a basic, quality LED with a nice pricepoint.EDIT 3/5/2012: Update 1080p content.  I've set up my streaming process to this TV with some 1080p material and it is gorgeous.  We recently watched Toy Story on this set, and I was blown away by the color depth and detail this TV displayed.  A small caveat: with all TVs, the speakers could use some improvement.  Set on the 'standard' audio output, the sound is fine.  If you set it to 'music' or 'movie', the audio sounds much better, but can rattle the TV's enclosure if the volume is set high.

Reviews.Title: Very pleased
Reviews.Author: wfc
Reviews.Content: As a grandmother who is not as technologically advanced as the younger generation, I did have concerns about buying a television that had to be programmed and the stand installed before using.  However, my fears were unwarranted.  As soon as I turned it on, I was stepped through the programming and the stand or base was very simple to install.  With the weight only being less than 15 pounds, I was also easily able to manuever it by myself.  I was watching programs within an hour although younger people would have managed all of this in fifteen minutes.My initial reason for wanting a newer television was due to my waning vision so had been looking into the 1080p with a 32" screen for some time.  I can't believe how much I can read on that screen now that wasn't clear to me before.  I had been advised that Samsung was one of most trustworthy brands, but found them locally to be out of my price range.  This one was reasonably priced and with my Amazon Prime membership was shipped to me free and quickly I might add.I am very pleased with the color and the sound plus the ease of use with the remote in case I do have to change the color or sound in the future.  I'm not thrilled with having to adjust the size of the picture when going from watching a news program with written information at the bottom of the screen to watching a movie, but it is easy to do so will just have to adjust to that feature.

Reviews.Title: Picture out the box = AWFUL... After calbration = AMAZING
Reviews.Author: Steguer Wilson
Reviews.Content: When I first took it out of the box and powered it on I was shocked at the picture. It looked awful UNTIL I read the other reviews about it being properly calibrated. So after tinkering around for what seemed hours I managed to get these setting based on Football and regular TV viewing:Mode: MovieBacklight: 18Contrast: 80Brightness: 40Sharpness: 20Color: 80Tint: G/R 58/44Under advanced setting;Dynamic Contrast: MediumBlack Tone: DarkerPicture tone: CoolFilm Mode: OffSound Mode: Movie

Reviews.Title: It doesn't get any better than this for the price
Reviews.Author: kevinharvick29
Reviews.Content: I am going to have to go out on a limb here and say that this is the most delightful TV I have had the privilege of owning. It's only my 2nd flat screen but I can still attest that this one is a keeper. The colors are great, the picture is crisp and you will find it to be an overall very pleasant viewing experience. I have not yet tried all of it's features but I did do some tweaking. There's not an overwhelming amount of options to choose from in the picture menu but it is definitely adequate. I would recommend this tv if you like the "set it and forget it" philosophy. It certainly makes things simpler and you get a great picture with the built in presets. If you do like to tweak then you can find a few things to play with but it is just not extensive. I like the music setting on the audio menu. I prefer the music preset. Let me advise you that this is the tv to beat in terms of audio quality. It is EXCELLENT in that department. The thing gets plenty loud at a low level but at the same time the lowest volume is not overly loud at all. I love it. There's a rich deep bass inherent to the set that I find difficult to eq out. At times it sounds a little odd but you get used to it and most of the times you will find yourself enjoying it. I have Comcast cable and this tv brings the music channels to life. I don't think I could have made a better choice for the money I paid. The screen works equally well as a computer monitor. You're going to have to go into the source menu and hit the tools function to change the name of the connection to PC or DVI to get it to look its best. I'm kind of bummed about there only being two hdmi connections but you can work around that with an hdmi switcher. I actually am only using one hdmi connection at the moment but I plan on getting a blu ray player soon. Good thing I moved this screen out of my computer setup and put it in the living room by itself. I can see the connections getting full really fast. By the way, the remote is awesome. It's compact and actually has a back light. I love the way the buttons smell too. TMI? Maybe. I do have to say that this tv is quite a bargain and there is not much that you will not like. Highly recommended.

Reviews.Title: A top mid-range TV; excellent in 'almost* every way
Reviews.Author: Christopher Engel
Reviews.Content: UPDATE: 8/3/2012 *massive* changes and deletions made to reflect the Eco settings and how to get the best picture possible with no regards to power consumption. Equally massive changes made for picture optimization with new discoveries.UPDATE: 6/28/2012 (various changes)***Let's just start off with what really matters: The only thing wrong with this TV is the unique "LED Motion Sensing" technology. In theory, this allegedly causes the backlight to have a "strobe" effect so as to enhance motion in a way similar to higher refresh rates, and, in theory, help with the problem of HDTV blurring. This is simply misleading marketing, as it does not, in fact, do that at any point, no matter how much I test with it on whatever scene. If it is indeed happening, I don't notice it.Now, if you've ever seen a high-end, larger TV, you can't help but notice the so-called "soap opera effect" (I'm not sure why it's called that--it just means the fluidity of the picture is far superior to a standard 60Hz rate, and is certainly impressive to look at). I, personally, was under the impression that I was practically stealing for this "LED Motion Sensing" with its variable 120Hz rate. Obviously, this isn't anywhere near the case, and it still operates as a smaller, more budget-friendly TV with a lot of good things about it.So what does LED Motion Sensing do? Well, it darkens the picture. That's as far as I notice any difference at all. However, on the bright side, it reduces power consumption very significantly. More on that in a bit.But, hey, it's cheap for a reason, right? A 1080p TV with a lot of other bells and whistles, often very easy to get at $400, which is the same price as the widely hailed king of mid-range TVs, Panasonic. I actually had returned a Panasonic Viera in favor of this, due to an obviously defective unit that had serious issues of constantly turning itself off and then only a specific hard reset for turning back on.One thing you can't knock this TV for is every other thing it houses. The picture quality, if tweaked correctly, is simply gorgeous. Blacks are so purely dark with no hint whatsoever of a washed-out picture. The option that allows the TV to detect flesh and boost its color works surprisingly well without looking ridiculous, even at the highest setting. I enjoy using this setting.You get a wealth of options at your fingertips, from tweaking the picture to obscene levels and changing various levels of whites, darks, colors, and dynamic contrast, as well as a variety of eco-friendly settings for those who care about energy consumption, like me. Let's run down the important settings, the first being an "optimal" picture with no concern for energy consumption, the second being for everyday use with energy consumption in mind, and also to prevent overheating.Okay! When it comes to generalized settings that work for pretty much any signal, but are best for 1080p HDMI 1.4 pictures, such as in Blu-rays, this is what I've come up with (if something is missing, consider it totally unchanged from default settings)Picture:Mode: MovieBacklight: 20Contrast: 100Brightness: 45 (this is *just* when the picture is about to become noticeably too bright, and darks no longer look dark enough.)Sharpness: 100 (incredibly, this TV can handle it without that horrible ultra-static and deformed picture effects--the native 1080p versus 720p can probably be given a hat tip for that)Color: 100 (This is actually important. See, the more a TV can give you color before it clearly becomes over-saturated is key in how vibrant the picture is and the TV's ability to process the colors. To my blessed surprise, a setting of a maxed-out 100 does not over-saturate, and things seem to look exactly as they should. However, your results may vary, and personal preference is part of this setting.)Gamma: +3Dynamic Contrast: Maxed outBlack Tone: Dark (the first setting below normal, not Darker or Darkest, which will make dark scenes far too difficult to see)-> All Eco settings turned off, including LED Motion Sensing.Color Space: NativeDynamic Contrast: HighFlesh Tone: +15 (has no apparently deleterious effect on emphasizing picture, but it does make it more vibrant)Color Tone: Mostly preference, but Warm1 seems to be best for me. Warm2 is too much red and Normal doesn't seem to be enough, although sometimes it does look better, depending on what's on the screen.Digital Noise Filter: High (DO NOT keep this at Auto. The TV AI does not do a good job of determining when this feature should be on and to what level. I see no problem at all with keeping this on High at all times, which drastically reduces noise, which is present on even 1080p sources.)LED Motion Plus: Off. As much as I want to say to keep this on, as it was a strong factor in my purchasing decision, I just can't find a real reason to. It sounds so good on paper, sure, but it just doesn't deliver what it promises at all. The drop in picture quality from keeping it on just isn't worth it, and I see absolutely no noticeable difference in fluidity due to the alleged "strobe" backlighting.FOR ECO-CONSCIOUS USERS: This is how you configure the most eco-friendly setting, "Standard", as opposed to "Movie". Be sure to switch these modes for practical reasons, and also because "Movie" does not allow for certain settings.Some of us just can't have our cake and eat it too. With the TV running at absolute max settings through and through, it's going to burn energy really, really fast. With regular use, your electric bills will reflect it.Now, the Eco features present here seem a lot more complicated than they really are. But ultimately, you can turn everything off except a couple of things.Note: There is the "Auto Eco" setting that does absolutely nothing but darken the picture, but even one notch below off is a strong difference. It's better to simply lower the backlight manually.To be conscious of your energy usage, keep the backlight at ten or lower instead of a constant 20. Turn LED Motion Sensing on (you might as well, since the picture's going to have less backlight, anyway), and, depending on how it works for you, choose whether or not to use motion sensing. Sometimes this setting can make the picture weird, like it's fading in and out way too fast to adjust to lighting. Sometimes it's not even noticeable. I, personally, keep it off. Really, the backlight is where all the energy consumption comes from, and simply lowering it, either manually or through the Auto Eco system (set to either Low or Medium is the farthest you can go while still seeing the picture--I can't imagine anyone tolerating lower than the Low setting, which I just can't stand)Final Notes:1. Do not use auto leveling of audio between inputs. The TV's way of handling this is very poor, and will give you distorted sounds all over the place if you use this. Just keep volume leveling options off.2. Game Mode doesn't really do anything except make the picture darker and less detailed. It also makes the screen have a strange but deliberate shaking motion, I guess to...I dunno, make explosions more realistic for your screen? I'm not sure. Either way, even if you're gaming, keep it off. The vast difference in picture quality definitely is not worth the sacrifice for the occasional screen shaking, its only apparent use.3. Don't forget to disable the inputs you don't use and to label the inputs you do use to prevent any confusion. Only 2 HDMI inputs is downright cruel, but thankfully, that's all I need. Anyone who needs more, though, shouldn't be looking at a 32" in the first place. What else do you plan to hook up to it besides maybe an HDTV box and a Playstation 3?4. While I can't confirm this myself, I've heard rumors that updating the firmware via a USB stick--including official firmware straight from samsung.com--voids your warranty, as it's considered tampering. Yeah, that sounds a little weird. I had already updated it before I read that, but someone else could probably clarify that much better than I could, if it's true.5. As of right now, the official firmware for the TV has not changed since I first purchased this. No need for any updating unless you haven't done it since June.Alright, that's that. Considering how much I got it for (about $400), this is truly an outstanding television with a spectacular picture quality, not to mention full 1080p support. For a display this small, the jump from 720p to 1080p is not all that significant, and unnoticeable unless you're specifically looking for it. Don't be fooled into thinking that, by default, 1080p means a much better picture than 720p. It doesn't, unless your television is at least 40 inches in size. However, what it *does* mean is that you can max out sharpness, color, contrast, and pretty much anything that benefits from a native 1080p resolution, which is unlike a 720p needing a downgrade, and subsequently requiring far different settings.I'll say it again: Good luck, fellow TV shoppers and consumerists.

Reviews.Title: Very, very nice.
Reviews.Author: jfcomposer
Reviews.Content: Just received the 32" version (without all the internet bells and whistles).The Good:- Excellent sharpness and well-saturated colors out of the box.  I did not need to tweak the TV as others have.  Perhaps I'm not as picky. :)- VERY light for its size.  I'm going to be mounting it on the wall, so this is a boon.- Worked like a charm plugging into the computer via HDMI, no hassles whatsoever (under Windows 7; Linux has not yet been tested)- Built-in speakers are respectable.- Looks very sexy with the thin borders around the screen (bevel).The so-so:- Only 2 HDMI, as others have stated.  Not an issue for me, but worth noting.- Thicker than I expected, but I can't justify lowering the rating as the dimensions are listed here. It's essentially the same thickness as a regular LCD of this size. Svelte it ain't.- Stand doesn't swivel or bend in any direction.- HDMI ports are on the side which makes cable management less pretty. With so much room and thickness on the back I'm surprised they couldn't put them there with the other plugs.- Getting used to messing with the settings using the power button knob on the bottom was... awkward.  Had to put the batteries in the remote to do it. Not really a big deal, just something to note.All-in-all I am very pleased with this TV.Hope this helps some potential buyers. :)

Reviews.Title: Beware! - Expensive TV With Cheap Panel
Reviews.Author: oibv305
Reviews.Content: I ordered the Samsung 40" UN40EH5000 tv from Amazon, expecting to receive a Samsung tv with a Samsung panel (Version TSO_x) for the $489.00 I paid. I received the Samsung tv, but I received one with a cheaper Sharp panel (Version HSO3). No problem, I contacted Amazon customer service and they authorized return of the tv with the Sharp panel and shipped a replacement 40" Samsung which I received the next day. When I opened the shipping box up and checked the sticker on the tv box I found I had received another Samsung with the cheaper Sharp panel again (HSO3). When I contacted Amazon customer service this time they advised that all the tvs in their warehouse were probably the HSO3 version with the cheaper Sharp panel, so I decided to send this one back as well. If I am buying a Samsung tv, I expect to get a Samsung tv, not a Samsung/Sharp tv. If the Samsung tvs with Sharp panels are all that Amazon has in their warehouse you will probably get the same thing if you order this tv.

Reviews.Title: Very happy with it
Reviews.Author: Ben
Reviews.Content: I am very happy with this tv. The picture is excellent, it has the inputs/outputs I wanted. Movies look great, bright colorful scenes are almost painful to look at (I had the brightness set too high). Overall set up was easy. I plugged my laptop into the tv via an hdmi cable and it looked great and was very easy to calibrate the size of the window. The speakers sound better than I thought they would, I think I will actually use them in addition to my stereo speakers. The tv itself is a nice design, the front is very seamless, giving it a smaller impact on the living room. I also really like how it is uses LED backlighting, which uses less energy and is much less toxic than ccfl backlit tvs. This was the only tv in this price range that I could find that used LED backlighting and also had good reviews on picture quality. I just wish they made a 37 inch version, I would have paid more for it.

Reviews.Title: Great LED..
Reviews.Author: bobo
Reviews.Content: I have always been a plasma guy. Not a fan of motion blur.. As I love movies and sports. But needed a 32 for the bed room. Smallest plasma tv are 42. Researched tons of tvs. Returned 2 Visio led razors as the picture was great but the sound was terrible.  This tv has great picture and very good sound. Movie and tru hd sound setting... Big plus.. Also best looking tv as it is mostly screen.  If you are looking for a very good LED tv  this is the one.

Reviews.Title: A panel fancy dress party! Yay!
Reviews.Author: Jeffrey Perumal
Reviews.Content: Pretty sure this item listing says it's a Samsung. The box I received (from Amazon on 11/23, paid $429) had Samsung on it. The badge on the TV said Samsung. So it's a Samsung, right? No! It's a Sharp dressed up as a Samsung! (version hs03) Weird, right? I thought I purchased a Samsung!And of course, this panel fancy dress party is totally legit - when I thought I was buying a Samsung, what I was in fact buying was a standard, a threshold above which there could be lots of variance in quality (such as an actual Samsung panel being better than a Sharp panel). So, just as in a lottery, the losers fund the winnings, a few unknowingly get lucky and win, and the house makes a killing! Ha! Ingenious!It's going back to Amazon - on my dime, yes, but rather that than encourage--no, reward!--this sort of merrymaking at our expense.UPDATE: this is about Amazon's great service - the return shipping was not on my dime as I initially suspected it might be; using the UPS pickup Amazon arranged was easy, Amazon did not charge me for the shipping, and provided a total refund, including the $3.99 I had paid for next-day when I bought it! Just more reason Amazon will continue to vacuum up pretty much all my discretionary dollars...Now if only Amazon would use its immense might to work with companies to stop or mitigate the sort of predatory profiteering exemplified by panel lotteries.

Reviews.Title: Excellent controls for an inexpensive TV.
Reviews.Author: J. Rice
Reviews.Content: Like most TVs, the picture out of the box is rather bright, oversaturated and cold.  Once I started digging into the settings I was quite surprised to see the level of control, which I had only known before on very high end models.  You have the regular settings such as brightness, contrast, sharpness, backlight and so on, which are usually enough to get a perfectly good image, but this TV also has a couple "Advanced" areas with some outstanding adjustments.  Most of the controls in those areas should probably be left alone for most people, but even if you do experiment with them, it is easy to get them back to normal by setting them to "0".  These are adjustments with controls for each individual RGB color which are outstanding for anyone with the knowledge to use than and a calibration disc.One unusual adjustment that gave a huge improvement for me was the "Gamma" which I dropped to -1.  This made a great improvement in making the TV appear more "Film Like".  Along with other common adjustments like reducing the contrast, color, brightness and making some small adjustment to the hue, usually a notch or two toward green so everyone doesn't look like they have sunburns.  But, the first adjustment is to set the color temperature to "Warm 2", which is the warmest setting and is still none too warm.  After seeing the distinctly blue cast of the TV out of the box, this may seem a little warm, but your eyes will recover quickly to see this is generally the best setting.  This should be done BEFORE any other picture settings because if it isn't, all the others will be thrown off with this change.Finally, the sharpness setting appears to be "off" at 50 (see update below), which is the initial setting.  If the goal is to have a smooth, pleasant, film like image, no extra sharpening should be used.  Typically, a lot of images are already sharpened too much to begin with and more just causes all sorts of artifacts.  Setting this much below 50 definitely UN-sharpens the image, which isn't good either.My goal is to get the smoothest, most pleasant and film-like image, so my suggestions won't be for everyone.  I do suggest anyone try them at some time, though.  It can be surprising how much nicer a gentle, well resolved image is over the harsh ones.Update 1/22/13:  I've had this TV for a couple months now and I am still quite happy with it.  Since then I learned about the various panels it comes with and mine appears to have a Sharp panel.  I also decided to get the 32" version as well, which appears to have a Samsung panel.  It may have a slightly better picture, but the difference is small.For anyone struggling with settings, I have set both units to the same calibration, and they both look quite good.  I see a lot of rather "hot" settings being posted here, so for anyone looking for a good starting point that is more "film like", this is what I have settled on with both TVs, so they are probably good starting points.Backlight: 18Contrast: 50Brightness: 48Sharpness: 35Color: 43Hue: G53/R47Gamma: -1Color Tone: Warm2The sharpness can probably go down a bit since I sometimes still see a little "ringing", and the Warm2 color tone setting still can tend to be too cool for my tastes.  Keep in mind that these aren't going to be best for all TVs or people, particularly the hue setting.  I find most of the other settings posted here are WAY too high on contrast, color and brightness.  I have NEVER seen any TV that looked good with those above the initial or middle setting.

Reviews.Title: Beautiful Picture - No extra's, but has just what you need!
Reviews.Author: Brian
Reviews.Content: I have a 5 year old Panasonic Viera plasma TV in my home theater and purchased this as a secondary set for the bedroom.  And after much research, multiple viewings at various stores, and deliberation i had narrowed my search down to Samsung and they happened to just release this new EH line and I took the plunge on impulse (no reviews or information was available on the new line) and... All I can say is, I am completely blown away by this televisions picture quality, clarity, and color reproduction... I enjoy watching this one better then my main TV.I am now looking to replace my main TV, mentioned above, with a larger new Samsung model... keep in mind that as both other reviewers have mentioned the connections are very limited (2 hdmi, 1 composite, 1 optical audio out, 1 usb),  So if you need more then that you should look at Samsung's higher end line. Personally, I have no need for all of the other bells and whistles, as if you use a receiver you don't need all of the connections anyway...Simply, Samsung saved some money on adding unnecessary goodies to this TV and instead focused on giving you an amazing LED lit, LCD screen that just beautiful and really performs... which, in my opinion, is the absolute most important aspect of purchasing a television.

Reviews.Title: Stung by Samsung
Reviews.Author: DOC
Reviews.Content: Stopped working after about 16 months. Spent an hour on phone trying to get some information. Was told it is out of warranty(12 months) but they gave me # to a local servicer, who immediately knew the problem-needed new smartboard. When I called Samsung back they said they hadn't heard of that problem for this model. If you go online you can find numerous reports of others who have had same problem . Clearly there is a defect in this. My old Sony and Panasonic never had any problems and even a no-name cheap flat panel I bought about 5 years ago still works just fine.

Reviews.Title: Great TV for a great price
Reviews.Author: Charles
Reviews.Content: I have to say that I am more than pleased with this tv.  For anyone that doesn't know, it is an LED LCD.  Prior units marked as just LCD used CCFL (Cold Cathode Fluorescent Lamps) for their backlight which draws more power and produces more heat.  The new wave are just being labeled LED and of course use LED's for the backlight which are much lower in power usage and produce virtually no heat.  I have read from other reviews that the panel is deeper/thicker than most LED tv's so I was not shocked when I pulled it out of the box.  It's still a thin TV for what it is, but I tend to think the added depth is for the speakers.  The picture quality is great after quite a bit of tweaking.  I tried using some settings other users have provided, but found using Dynamic mode to be way over saturated and blown out.  I also found that using my PS3 and Xbox360 over HDMI would suffer from overscan, which basically takes what the game system is sending it and making the edges of the image be on the outside of the screen creating a zoomed in picture.  HDMI1 is also labeled as DVI and is suppose to disable overscan for use with a computer or console, but I still noticed some overscan going on.  Changing the label of the HDMI ports to PC will disable overscan completely but also disables the use of Dynamic and Movie modes if done to HDMI2.  To change the labels, just open the Menu, navigate to Inputs and then select Edit Names.  Both my systems looks amazing on this tv, I could not be happier.  The settings I use (which are suited to my tastes) are listed below, hopefully it will give someone a base as to where to start.  I keep the brightness low and the backlight up higher to reduce washout and keep black screens from glowing.Mode = StandardBacklight = 16Contrast = 100Brightness = 45Sharpness = 80Advanced SettingsGamma = 0Picture OptionsColor Tone = StandardHDMI Black Level = LowOverall sound quality from the speakers is not bad for what it is, definitely sounds better than alot of other TV's, but I would suggest using a receiver/stereo for audio playback.  It does have an optical audio out and can support Dolby Digital output but not over HDMI. I have read this is due to not being able to decode Dolby over HDMI, so output for SPDIF (optical) is stuck at PCM.  My panel shows no signs of backlight bleed or any fogging/flashlighting from the backlight and 0 dead pixels.  Prior to this unit I had a no name TV that I tried out due to being alot cheaper in price, but unfortunately that was definitely a case of you get what you pay for.  Screen had terrible backlight bleed and cloudiness scattered all over the panel and colors were no where near as good as this Samsung model.

Reviews.Title: Not for close up action
Reviews.Author: C. W.
Reviews.Content: I won't waste a lot of time repeating what others have said about this being a good TV. My big complain is that the "120 Clear Motion Rate" is the pipe dream of some engineer at Samsung or a con by their marketing department. If you try watching a programme with a close up of fast action it fails terribly. You get the ghosting or distortion as the TV cannot display that large of an image moving that fast. Samsung should have simply been honest up front. I bought this model because of the claims about the Clear Motion. I would that I had ignored them and just bought a real 120hz Samsung.

Reviews.Title: Very good for the price
Reviews.Author: JD
Reviews.Content: I am pleasantly surprised with the TV.  The sound is a lot better than I thought it would be and after a few tweaks, the picture is good in SD and great in HD.I like the added touch of being able to play movies, music, and pictures with the USB drive.  Another quality product from Samsung.  Makes a perfect bedroom TV.

Reviews.Title: Good picture. Bad black levels. Minimal features.
Reviews.Author: Daniel Oliver
Reviews.Content: Right out of the box, the picture did not impress me at all. After some tweaking and some googling, however, I got it to look pretty good. I'm mostly happy with the picture quality with a couple of caveats: black levels and motion handling.The motion handling is what first jumped out at me. However, I find the longer I have the TV, the less I notice it. Personally, I think it's one of those things you have to look for to really notice on this TV.On the other hand, the poor black levels are definitely noticeable in day-to-day watching. In very dark scenes, the darker areas of the screen can become very blocky and pixelated. Now, I have a suspicion that some of this is caused from my cable box, but I know not all of it is. Unfortunately I don't have a Blu Ray player to confirm either way.I know at least one other reviewer mentioned this, but Samsung outsourced the panel manufacturing on these TVs to different companies. This can result in very different picture quality from one TV to another, and there's really no way to tell which one you have until you get the TV plugged up and go into the factory set up screen. I didn't know this until after buying the TV. If I had, I probably would've looked elsewhere. I looked up my panel, and I believe it's from a Chinese company called AUO. This panel has a very poor viewing angle. You can still see the picture from the side, but it's noticeably washed out, like there's a fog on the screen.A few more annoyances:1. The coaxial audio input on the back of the TV doesn't seem right on my TV. It's just a plastic piece with a hole in it and doesn't really look like any other coax input I've ever seen. I've tried to hook up a set of speakers with different audio cables and I haven't been able to get a really good "fit". I'm using 3.5mm/mini-jack, like the manual says, but it still results in a loud buzzing sounds like something isn't connected right. I'm beginning to think it's just a malfunction with my TV, but I just switched to optical audio to bypass the problem.2. If you use external speakers, like a 2.1 system without a receiver, the TV won't control the volume of the external speakers. This is a HUGE oversight on Samsung's part. My 5 year old 32inch Sharp LCD has this feature, I don't understand why a new TV like this wouldn't. This should be a standard on all TVs nowadays.Those two problems don't really affect me, since I have a soundbar and receiver that handles all of the audio, but I know it could be a dealbreaker for a lot of people.Bottom line, I wouldn't buy this TV again because of the lack of features, but I don't dislike it enough to send it back either. The picture quality is very good for the most part, unless it's a really dark scene. Which is good enough for me.UPDATE 6/21/2013: I mentioned the blocky pixelating in darker scenes possibly being caused by my cable box in my earlier review, and I think that was definitely the case. I've recently moved and switched to DirecTV. I don't notice this issue any longer.I have to say as time goes by, I am more satisfied with this TV. Now, that is probably the case with any TV you buy. If you have something long enough, you stop looking for flaws and just enjoy it for what it is. I do find myself admiring the picture quality of this set more and more. The viewing angles are still not great (I have mine in a corner of a narrow-ish room so not really an issue), and darker scenes could be better, but overall I am more happy with this TV now that when I first bought it. All of my initial observations still stand though, so I'm leaving my rating at 3 stars.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic
Reviews.Author: brent
Reviews.Content: Picture is great.  I picked this television out in a showroom because the picture was just as good as the plasma tvs. And the price was half as much as some other LED tvs that don't have half as good a picture.  Also, this tv does not produce that dreaded soap opera effect when watching celluloid films. Not as thin as some of the other LED tvs, but the bezel is very small and the tv is thin at the ends. Unless, you plan to hang this on a wall and super thin is your priority, this is an unbeatable tv.  No bells and whistles though.

Reviews.Title: Samsung should RECALL this model
Reviews.Author: HenryC "HenryChorley"
Reviews.Content: After only 16 months of light usage, this set has begun to ARC: it makes snap, crackle pop noises and that is considered too dangerous to operate, because it could start a fire or badly shock a person. I have checked on the Internet and found customers from Europe, Asia, and North America making similar complaints about this Samsung model or others produced in early 2012. The capacitors are cheap and have failed, owners say. It cost $400 when new and Amazon says I can't return it. Surely it should have lasted for more than 16 months? I was about to buy the same model for another room in the house, but no more. Samsung has flooded the market with cheap, poorly-built products and I will no longer be their customer.

Reviews.Title: Buyer Be Ware...Buyer forwarning ...do research before buying!
Reviews.Author: Carolina Blue "Love is NOT meant to hurt!"
Reviews.Content: I bought this television, not on Amazon but I did purchase it at a store on a military base.... I have had nothing but problems with it. The first time while under warranty, the television started to show horizontal colored lines through the television.  I contacted Samsung and they said it what I was experiencing was a known defect and that they had to replace my television with a new one.  Then the television that they replaced it with then had another issue with it not being responsive and not shutting off when it was suppose to and then when I did get it turned off it wouldn't come back on. While Samsung covered that under a known issue and sent a technician to my residence to replace one of two parts that was known to cause this to happen, to me two televisions with the same model having two different issues and having Samsung fix them shows something that Samsung knows that they have issues with their product and they are fixing it, but it would be a much better product if it wasn't necessary for me to call Samsung customer service to repair my television to begin with.

Reviews.Title: Awesome TV for an even better price
Reviews.Author: Shadow Raven
Reviews.Content: If you want a high quality tv, with a reliable brand, without sticker shock, this is the tv for you. I bought it to replace a 40" Sony that was in my living room. I was tempted to buy a tv that was larger but this had the best value in tv size and price. I've almost always have bought Sony products. However, it seemed like the Sony TV was just as good for about $100 more. I would recommend this tv to almost anyone. Multiple reviewers mention that it isn't calibrated correctly at first. I think it's great as it is (although I like to tweek almost any tv). Unlike some flat panel tvs these days it also has awesome soun

Reviews.Title: Great as a Computer Monitor!  Speakers are good too!
Reviews.Author: Bruce A. Pinkham Jr.
Reviews.Content: UPDATE 12-16-2012I still love this monitor as my computer monitor.  However, I did discover that this monitor does not "wake from sleep" or "turn on when a video signal is present", like most computer monitors do.  I wrote Samsung about this, and they replied (just part of the message):We are sorry for any problems this may be causing you. The first problem is that this is not a monitor, it's a tv, we do have monitors this size. This is the reason the tv is not going into sleep mode with the computer.The rest of the message was just polite comments, but this was the only line specific to my question.END OF UPDATE 12-16-2012I do not mean for this to be a complete review.UN32WH5000FVersion TS01 (I won the Samsung TV Lottery!!)Firmware, T-MX9FAUSC-1017.1. (firmware that came with TV out of the box - I did not do any firmware upgradeVery impressed with both the video AND the audio as my primary computer monitorI hooked this up with a Displayport to HDMI cable Cable Matters Gold Plated Premium DisplayPort to HDMI Male to Male Cable in Black 6 ft.  11 dollars or so, and well worth it!Use a digital connection (DVI-HDMI-Displayport) whenever available, not analog (VGA - Component) when hooking up a computer to a monitor.Turn down SHARPNESS to ZERO for very clear text.  If memory serves, "sharpness" is actually a form of distortion invented many years ago when everyone used "off the air" signals" and "sharpness" made the picture look better.  Turning SHARPNESS down to ZERO makes the text very readable!Also, I had to choose the ASPECT RATIO of "Fit to Screen Size" Unter the TV MENU button on Remote - PICTURE- PICTURE OPTIONS - VIDEO - SCREEN OPTIONS SIZE - SCREEN FITVery happy with this monitor as my primary computer monitor!Update - Interesting!  If you change the name of the HDMI 1 imput to PC or DVI PC or DVI, the setting change to give you pretty much perfect settings for using the TV as a monitor.  Remote control Menu Sorce List then hit the Remote Controll TOOLS button, and you can select one of those three options.

Reviews.Title: Perfect for gaming
Reviews.Author: Alex
Reviews.Content: I was having a hard time choosing between this Samsung and Panasonic TC-L32E5, but in the end I chose Samsung and have no regrets. TC-L32E5 is thinner, but Samsung is lighter in weight and has a very narrow bezel. In addition, my primary purpose is to use it with a PC, which is really easy to set up on a Samsung (you just edit the input name to PC-DVI). I also set backlight to 18 and contrast to 85 as did another reviewer. I mostly play video games, and it looks amazing from about 6 feet away. If you are going to sit further than that I recommend that you go with 40" and higher. The surround HD sound mode is great.My only minor complaints are that it's not as thin as the more expensive ES series, and that the base mount is like that of older models (attached with screws and cheap-looking comparing to the TV itself). My guess is that this is the best they could do in this price range.

Reviews.Title: Buyer Beware!  All negative reviews of this TV are true!
Reviews.Author: Michael
Reviews.Content: Here is a list of problems I have experienced with the Samsung UN40EH5000.  You may notice that previous reviewers in the negative review area had these problems too.  I wish I listened.Look at this TV in a showroom.  Don't be fooled into thinking your purchase will be OK.  Look at the picture and you will see small distortions in the picture.  I wish I listened to myself.Some models of this TV do not have a full Samsung panel.  I have a panel with the code HS03 (which you can see on the box) which is made by Sharp and is lower in quality than the full Samsung panel.  A previous reviewer read that the HS03 panel had ghosting problems.  This is true.  Please see the previous review, "Many DON'T HAVE SAMSUNG PANELS - HUGE quality difference".Screen is reflective and you can see yourself in the TV at some angles.  This is true too.This TV has terrible 480i conversion to 1080p.  Previous reviewer commented that Comcast does not look good on this TV.  This is profoundly true to me.  Watching cable TV I noticed distortions around character's faces, especially the eyes.  Sometimes a face would stick in place for a second or blur.  Sometimes backgrounds had a ripple effect.  People also moved in and out of focus.  All of this lead to making me feel dizzy.  The TV picture does take a lot of tweaking the settings to look good.  However, I see no point to this while watching cable TV.  I must also add picture quality is pixilated while watching cable.  Turning on Samsung's Clear Motion Rate 120 feature did help, but only a little bit. It did not fix the poor picture quality.I did chat with Samsung about all of this.  I performed a in TV diagnostic for them.  My TV displayed a screen of test color bars, which did look OK, but this doesn't diagnose the problems I was having.  Samsung should have a diagnostic that plays a short video for you to truly see what's going on.  The tech support chat host wasn't able to fix my problems.I did chat with a Comcast tech support person.  They re set my cable box.  This didn't help the problem.This TV is boxed up in a filmy package!  The box I got had a hole it in right in front of the TV screen.  There was nothing in between!  On inspection the TV was undamaged.  I think these TV should have more foam packaging inside for protection.  That was a close one.The picture quality on my 24 inch Toshiba 1080p HDTV while watching cable is excellent.  I didn't pay near $500 for a 40 inch great TV to have all of these problems!  Thank heavens that Amazon has a good return policy!  Amazon arranged for a UPS pickup next day and will be refunding my money.Having said all of this, this TV did look good to me when I played a DVD on a player with 1080p up conversion.  I give credit for that.  However, I feel the model should work well with 480i as well.  I know 480i won't give me a great picture when blown up to 40 inches, but the UN50EH5000 looked unacceptable in this instance.This year I have purchased about three Samsung products.  All three have malfunctioned on me.  I am not buying their brand anymore.  I have to do some careful searching now.  I am looking at LG.

Reviews.Title: Lasted 3 months
Reviews.Author: Matt Hertel
Reviews.Content: Had it for three months before a horizontal row of dead pixels showed up.  Worked great before that, I would assume the panels for this TV are not made by Samsung, they seem to lack the quality I've come to expect from them.

Reviews.Title: Annoyed and there's nothing you can do about it
Reviews.Author: jordie24
Reviews.Content: Overall the TV is great out of the box...good picture, good sound, easy setup, awesome delivery / packaging by Amazon. The biggest disappointment is the info display.  That being...every time you change the HD channel, and it has a different size or whatever, this HUGE and ANNOYING pop-up display comes up in the LHand corner.  It says something like "HDMI-1, 1920x1080/60p and the current time".  It stays on for about 3-4 seconds.  So if your channel surfing, this thing keeps popping up....you sit there and look at it saying to yourself, "go away....go away...go away...GO AWAY"...and it does so about 3-4 seconds later.I called Samsung (after jacking around trying the internet and/or the instruction manual for 2 hours) to find out how to turn it off.  After being on HOLD for almost an hour (at 11 p.m. EST) I get a rep that tells me, "Yeah, this cannot be turned off because it's a factory setting".  WHAT!!!!!  WHO CARES and WHO NEEDS to know every time the thing changes...I dont.  This is like taking your brand new car to the dealer because the engine is making a bad grinding noise...only to have the tech tell you to turn up the radio louder so you don't hear the engine noise.This might be a deal breaker for me....going to have to see if the annoyance factor wanes over the next couple days...if not, the TV is going back to Amazon and I'll find something better.  Thanks Samsung.UPDATE - The very next day after receiving this TV, Amazon reduced the price by $15.  Now this TV has that "TV Low Price Guarantee" that says "If we lower our own price within 14 days after we ship your order, let us know and we will refund you the difference as well."  Contacted Amazon and Merlyn took care of this via chat (and it only took about 5 minutes)...AMAZON ROCKS!!!!!

Reviews.Title: MESMERIZING!
Reviews.Author: Ro7068
Reviews.Content: I purchased this TV after reading all the excellent reviews. When I first took it out of the box and hooked it up to my existing cable, I was extremely disappointed. Thankfully, I called my Cable company and didn't return the TV, which was my first inclination.  With a few tweaks of the cable set up (I have no idea what he did), the quality of the picture is out of this world! I have never seen a clearer, sharper picture on any TV! And it is not hooked up to an HDMI cable, they used the component connection. I have to say that the sound is actually extremely good as well.  I have a 50" LG Plasma in the Living Room and I thought that picture quality was good, but it can't hold a candle to this TV! However, I do think it's odd that they put the two HDMI cable slots and the USB port on the side of the TV. A bit awkward if your TV fits as close to the sides of the cabinet as mine does. But, for the Bedroom TV, it can't be beat! Nor can it's price.  Grab it.  You won't be disappointed!

Reviews.Title: Best of the Selection!
Reviews.Author: Corky Beachglow "Animation Designer"
Reviews.Content: I purchased the Samsung UN32EH5000 32-Inch 1080p 60Hz LED HDTV and am IMPRESSED! After UPS delivered the box with a big hole punched into the side of the box (behind the screen)-- I thought about my longboard that was similarly skewered at the Honolulu airport by the locals who handle the luggage (meant to discourage haoles they say). Shame on UPS. I checked and the hole was punched in the back area of the box during shipment, away from output panel and all the delicate stuff, fortunately. Anyway, being a former CRT owner, I didn't know what to expect.The 32" screen was thinner than I expected and the whole set-up much lighter than some I saw at the local store. Set-up was relatively easy, but it took a while to dial-in the picture. I set the screen onto a swivel stand with my Bose center speaker and now both swivel. NOTE: Unless you are planning on buying a BlueRay DVD player, think twice about the 1080 resolution as my DVD player, even though it upscales the 720p native DVD to 1080p, is still not as sharp as if the screen rez were 720p as well....in other words, HDTV is extraordinary and when I get around to replacing my DVD player with a BLUE RAY, all will be sharp as a pinhead! Until then, my TV reception by cable (HD) is out of this world, but my DVD viewing isn't what it will be with a player that outputs actual 1080 rez images too. Proactively upgrading to 1080p can be a headache unless your input is also full HD & 1080p. I could've lived with a 720p machine but didn't see it except as a LCD which I wouldn't suggest owning. Samsung has come a long way in the past couple of decades, with quality manufacturing and advanced features. I have a HDMI cable connection (3 on board) and my DVD player upgrades and sound becomes DTS which is excellent. I don't play games or plug-in outboard devices into the set. A firmware upgrade from Samsung, downloaded to a stick and uploaded to the set via a USB plug-in went like clockwork and I think improved the picture. Samsung upgrade does NOT nullify the warranty by the way so no worries....just be careful and let the device complete the task before powering-down or disconnecting the flash memory device.A great set for the aprox. $400 price. Amazon rocks again!

Reviews.Title: excellent picture, lightweight, dark blacks.
Reviews.Author: dktt
Reviews.Content: Was looking for a 32" or 40" for my room. I had a 23" samsung 720p lcd for around 6 years. It was great, but was ready to upgrade. Had a $100 amazon gc so decided to give this model a chance. Wow, it has been great so far. The blacks are so dark, that you would swear the tv was off. Since it is an LED tv, it is very light weight, although it is much thicker than you would think for an led tv. The bezel is very thin, though, so all in all, it looks great (from the front). Only has 2 hdmi connections, but since it is in my room, I only needed 2 max. It is perfect for my needs and I am glad I purchased it.

Reviews.Title: No Screws!!!
Reviews.Author: Leslie M Corcoran "RNnofool"
Reviews.Content: This review is about Samsung customer service. I bought this TV on Black Friday for my husband for Christmas. We decided to set it up on New Years Eve. We opened the box and found there were no screws to attach the tv to the stand. We were disappointed but that was OK, mistakes happen. We called the number provided by the Samsung directions booklet. The first person we spoke to said there was nothing she could do to help us. So then we spoke to a supervisor and there was nothing she could do. We then asked to speak to someone who could do something. We received a call back the next day and this person said he couldn't do anything but give us the name of a company that we could BUY the screws from. See the problem was we had owned the TV for approximately 34 days. Samsung would only be responsible for 30 days of customer service. We could not accept this as our problem so my husband called the corporate offices. Surely they would be appalled at such a stupid policy. We then received a call from a person that told my husband right off the bat that he had reached the top of the company and there was no need to try to go further. He said this was Samsungs policy and we would have to purchase the screws even though they forgot to put them in the box. We have a houseful of Samsung TVs. Good price for a fairly good TV. We certainly can pay for the screws which we have done twice, once by the original purchase and again by the company that sells the screws Samsung forgets to put in the box. They must forget screws quite often if they have a go to company. During all this time we were wasting my husband took the Samsung inventory list from the TV and went to 2 hardware stores. The screws pictured had a Samsung number but not a number the hardware store could identify.  We had no choice but to order the screws from the company Samsung uses for their mistakes. We ordered the 8 screws which cost $25.00 with S&H.; The screws we received would have cost us .30 cents each at the hardware store if we had the correct size from what was pictured on the inventory list. The point is how could they not send us screws for the sake of .30 cents each! How could a multi million dollar company put a policy in place that slaps the customer in the face for buying their product. Are they so big, rich and arrogant that a bad review is a joke and means nothing? Also what about customer loyalty and standing by their product. These screws were not uncommon and could be bought out of a hardware store if the measurements were included. Would you believe there is a specific company that makes and sells the screws Samsung forgot to put in the box and some unlucky sap like my husband has to wait to use his TV and pay twenty times the amount of the value of the screws. Our loyalty to Samsung has taken a big hit. I think we will take another look at Sony, Panasonic etc. I 'm sure there is a good TV out there with much better customer service. Oh by the way I can't give a review on the quality of the TV yet because we just got the screws yesterday. I will be back with a fair honest review but I will no longer will be a loyal customer.  So unfortunate.....LCWe did finally get the screws last week and the TV is great after a lot of tweaking.  Samsung does have a great product (5 star) but a -5 star for service and loyalty.  LC  Addendum: I sent this message approximately 1 week ago 2/14/14 to Samsung Executive Customer Service Dept.  Dear Ceo, I thought you may be interested in the following problem my husband went through trying to set up a TV. I''m hoping all my efforts will make some sort of impact. I no longer want to here from all the Samsung peons that do not see the real problem in this very anti-customer service policy. Why do I have to keep jumping thru hoops? Do not think for one moment this is about a refund for screws. Try to envision the ridiculous process a customer has to go thru after spending a pretty substantial amount of money to a company they have repeatedly purchased productsfrom.  This is the response I received: Thank you for contacting Samsung Electronics, Office of the President. Your feedback is very important and we appreciate the opportunity to respond.I apologize you have been frustrated with your recent customer service experience and that the screws for your product were not included. We make every effort to provide our customers with an exceptional experience every time. Please understand the information provided by our customer service division was correct in to which I understand is only part of your frustration. Although this is the case, I can make an exception in this matter and offer to compensate you a portion of the cost. I can offer a $25.00 gift card from Best Buy.I am very sorry for any inconvenience this may have caused you and greatly appreciate the feedback.Please acknowledge your acceptance of this offer by replying to the email.Kind Regards, x  I responded to this offer:  My review regarding Samsung's customer service policy will remain the same but I will address this communication regarding the inability of Samsung's ERMS department to inadequately address the problem. This feeble response to mollify us is so unacceptable. Do you think an explanation of why Samsung feels the customer should be financially responsible for their own company errors would be to much to ask for? Do you feel $25. is enough to cover my time, or the verbally rude responses from the different departments we spoke to at Samsung to try to get the screws, the gas in my car back and forth to the hardware stores, the phone calls, the shipping charges for the super inflated price of the screws. I would like this communication past on to someone who can really compensate us for all our time and effort and most of all our increasing resolve to take this to the highest level we can. Instead of a Best Buy certificate maybe you should contact the department that packs the Samsung products and offer these employees a $25.00 yearly bonus to pay better attention to there jobs. Or maybe I just have the whole concept of this policy all wrong. Does Samsung get a percentage from these mistakes? Is it possible these really are not mistakes? Oh, I must be wrong. Why would a billion dollar company be so petty and need such an insignificant amount of money to add to their coffers? Can't be. It has to be that customer satisfaction and company integrity and loyalty is only for the most profitable end-users. I will use the utmost care to not pass on any employee names as I pass along my communications to various reviewer sites, Facebook, BBB, Consumer reports, Yelp and so on.  This was the end of my message. There may seem to be gaps here and there in all this correspondence but it contained names and addresses that should not be published. Thanks for reading. If I ever get that $25.00 gift certificate I will be donating it to a homeless shelter. Thanks so much for all those reading my posts.

Reviews.Title: excelent tv
Reviews.Author: jose
Reviews.Content: i love this tv the image is clear and beatiful, the sound is increible i don't buy a home theater, simply not needed, very happy with my buy, this image not present flags when see the soccer or other sports, simply excelent!!!!UPDATE 03/05/2014After a month of searching different configurations to test the best picture on the TV, I can say that I've got, I am fascinated by sports especially soccer, it's amazing picture and sound simply fantastic, the image has no ghosting and the sound is 5.1 dolby soundrraund, you can not ask for more, indeed I am quite satisfied with my purchase, I recommend the following settings if they like the real tone.IMAGEMode: DynamicBacklight: 17Contrast: 88Brightness: 46Definition: 88Color: 50Tint (V / R): V55/R45Color Tone: normalMovie Mode: AutoLED Motion Plus: OnI can see both channels as Standart HD with vivid clarity, simply excellent for both formats, the sound is no set q even, is simply perfect for me, I hope I've helped you with my opinion, I like to read suggestions, thanks.

Reviews.Title: Horrible Customer Service
Reviews.Author: Jo
Reviews.Content: When we received the TV, there was no TV stand in the box. We contacted Amazon and they told us to try and resolve the issue with Samsung. We contacted Samsung and they said they'd send it (after they requested serial numbers, order numbers, receipts and several other proofs of purchase). The TV stand never came. I contacted them again, went through the same conversation, they said they'd send it, it never came, and so on... repeated several times over the next few weeks. Finally, the last time I called them, they said they wouldn't send it because too much time had passed and we were past our warranty. (?!?!?!)I contacted Amazon and they handled the situation in a matter of minutes to my satisfaction.Moral of story... Samsung customer service sucks. But Amazon has your back.

Reviews.Title: Very nice TV for $$
Reviews.Author: Hilda
Reviews.Content: This is my second purchase of a Samsung product from Amazon.  I am not very technical so I was simply looking for a TV from a reputable company with positive reviews from others.I was very pleased with this purchase.  The TV picture quality is amazing.  The remote control was very easy to use and the features of the TV were not complicated as so many other products in the market place.Pros:  This TV is very user friendly for the "non-technical" user.  High definition picture quality is amazing.  TV is quite affordable.Cons:  None as of yet.

Reviews.Title: Samsung 32 inch 1080p LED HDTV
Reviews.Author: Darryl
Reviews.Content: My recent purchase of the Samsung LED HDTV further strengthened my commitment to the company and their products. The TV gives an excellent picture and sound quality while saving on electricity as well as ambient heat production. The contrast creates excellent black areas and makes easy to read any text displayed. It was easy to set up on its stand and make connections to cable and make all the correct settings. I would highly recommend this television to anyone who wants to save energy while getting a great high definition picture. The TV was purchased at Amazon and arrived in tact and ahead of schedule.

Reviews.Title: Bad TV, worse customer service
Reviews.Author: Gary D. Wilson
Reviews.Content: I bought this TV on 9/9/12 from another retailer.  Just wanted to let people know that there are now white lines going across the TV an no amount of auto repair or tinkering with the settings is making any difference.  I tried to contact Samsung, but there is no way to talk to someone in person, just have to fill out an online repair request.  So even though the TV is still under warranty, I have to pay for shipping to get it fixed, and it will take up to 28 days to get it repaired/replaced, of course this depends on how fast it can get shipped there and back.As far as the picture goes before the set went bad, I didn't like that to get full color without the washed out look, you had to sit directly in front of the TV.  I have a plasma in the main living room and have never had that issue with the plasma.  The picture quality is OK, but very difficult to not get that washed out look on certain channels.  As of right now I wish I hadn't bought it, but will have to see if it's any better after getting fixed.  If not, I'll be looking at another plasma set, and not a samsung.

Reviews.Title: Couldn't be happier
Reviews.Author: D. Murphy
Reviews.Content: Ordered this TV when the price dropped for Black Friday week.  It arrived in less than 48 hours.  Very easy to set up, stand is more solid and stable than a lot of other big flat panels.  Right out of the box the picture is very good - I'll play with the settings and tweak it but it really is "plug and play".  The sound quality was a big surprise - better than I had expected.  Remote is decent, and menu functions are easy to navigate and fairly intuitive.I wanted a basic but high quality TV which will mainly be connected to a cable DVR, and couldn't be happier with this one - especially for the price.  Picture quality using component cables to the Time Warner DVR is outstanding.  This set exceeds my expectations and is a terrific value.

Reviews.Title: If you use an antenna with a rotor DO NOT BUY ANY SAMSUNG TV
Reviews.Author: Steve S.
Reviews.Content: Unlike most other brands, neither this TV nor any Samsung TV (according to their tech support dept) will let you add channels to your already memorized channels.  This means that if you pick up 5 channels with your rotor in one direction, and 6 more in another direction, every time you want to see what is on a channel that requires moving the antenna rotor, you must reprogram the TV to be able to see the new channels.  All the previously memorized channels are erased every time!This is plain poor design.  I am very disappointed in Samsung around this issue.  I have not had this problem with LG or Visio TV's They have a function that allows adding channels to existing memorized channels.Other than this issue the TV was fine and shipping from Amazon was very fast.

Reviews.Title: Label Your Input Sources!! (Especially for PCs)
Reviews.Author: Gary
Reviews.Content: I've had this screen for 8 months and it has served me very well. I use it as my PC monitor and with my game consoles.Something to be wary about is that to get this TV to function at its best takes some doing. The menus for adjusting the picture are a bit scattered, but the general picture controls will get your color where you need it to be. Personally, I don't have any of the "motion lighting" features on as I don't notice a significant difference beside the screen getting darker. Honestly the screen is probably fine if you're just going to watch TV and aren't picky about the colors being perfect. And if you are, it won't take you too much to get there, just know you'll need to spend some Time adjusting.Now the biggest thing, which actually prompted this review, is that I have also been using this TV for my computer monitor. However, when the HDMI is connected to my PC, I had to scale down the desktop and work in a resolution less than 1080p or my the visuals would get cropped. The screen would also auto adjust contrast as the images changed on screen, which was horrid whenever I would edit images. I figured these were just what I was going to have to deal with using a TV as a monitor, as I did not see an option in the menus to remedy these.Until today.I was flipping through the menus fiddling with setting when I saw "source list" near the bottom. This setting in other TVs is usually just to assign names to your inputs for your organization pleasure. I figured since I was there I would label them. Source List->Edit Name. Lo and behold when I set my PC's input to PC/DVI it not only labeled it, but actually changed the way the screen treated the input! The screen no longer auto adjusted contrast, and I didn't need to scale my desktop to fit!I felt silly that it was so simple and I'm sure it's mentioned in the manual someplace, but it is not immediately obvious that this is what the setting does. So I thought I would post this review to maybe give a heads up to someone who might use this screen for the same purpose.So yeah! I'm even more stoked with this screen now!

Reviews.Title: Great value
Reviews.Author: Aaron E Hemmer
Reviews.Content: This TV doesn't have internet capability or 3D, and it's not super-slim, but it's better than most TVs that do have those features.  It has a beautiful picture - the across the screen LED lighting is superb to edge lit LED TVs.  It is a little light on HDMI ports, but if you use a receiver for audio, that's not a problem.  The sound isn't that great (to be expected from a thin TV), but it gets the job done.

Reviews.Title: GORGEOUS PICTURE!
Reviews.Author: D. J. Auerbach "dja"
Reviews.Content: My friends recommended a SamsungTV over some less costly brands. I am so glad I listened to them and held out for the "good stuff", the HD picture is awsome. NOT happy with the sound quality of the built in TV speakers - easily improved by buying a Samsung sound bar for that "home theater" experience. Oh, yeah!

Reviews.Title: FABULOUS!
Reviews.Author: Luigi Chincochento
Reviews.Content: This is the third Samsung I have purchased. I bought this 32", 5000 Series for my mother. Straight out of the box, it was easy to assemble (TV Stand), with the total setup time taking approximately 15 minutes. Version of this flat screen is TSO1. Based on previous reviews, this has a Samsung Panel and NOT a panel from some other manufacturer.If you have cable through Comcrap or a similar provider, you will disregard the cable setup on screen during the initial setup once your unit is powered up. Cable setup uses a preferred HDMI cable plugged into your High Definition (HD) equipped cable box. Plug one end of the cable to the HDMI input of the cable box, and the other end will connect to the HDMI IN 1 (DVI) jack of your TV. I recommend you hook everything up first, and plug the AC cable to the TV last. Once everything is set, take off all the protective tape and power up the unit. Once it's powered up, you will skip the initial cable setup that appears after selecting your language, date, time, daylight savings time, etc. With the initial setup complete, hit the "Source" button on your remote to select HDMI 1 on your TV. With HDMI1/DVI highlighted and selected, hit the "Tools" Button on your remote to Edit the Name. Here, you can select Cable STB, which stands for Cable Set Box. Further setup instructions for your HD Cable box (if you didn't have one previously) are supplied by your cable company.I have read some reviews that complained about a "tingy sound." I have not experienced that in the least and also recommend that you turn on the SRS TruSurround HD. I have always enabled this option with other Samsung TV's. You get to this option by pressing the "Menu" button on the remote, scroll once to the speaker icon titled "Sound", and scroll right to "SRS TruSurround HD" and turn "On". This option will add a fuller and richer sound.The remote ONLY illuminates as you depress any key, but will not illuminate in motion as compared to some of the higher end Samsung models. If the remote doesn't illuminate as you press keys, press the light bulb icon of the remote once. The button is located in the upper far right position. Once illumination is set, any future use will automatically turn off within approximately 2 seconds after pressing a button. Having to press a key to get the remote to illuminate is a bit of a nuisance because pressing a button just doesn't illuminate the remote; it will also enable whatever feature is associated with that button. I wish Samsung would make the remote on their lower end models illuminate on motion, but it is what it is. The illuminated remote is GREAT for seeing what you're doing while viewing at night. Once you have used the remote enough, you can memorize or pretty much figure out what button you will be pressing. If you have cable, you can program your cable remote to operate the TV and the TV remote is then placed in a drawer and used minimally.I will update this review as the TV is used, but so far, we are very happy with this purchase!

Reviews.Title: Great Value TV
Reviews.Author: szd -seattle
Reviews.Content: Bought this to be used as a TV in a small room without external speakers or other 'media room' accessories. Not using it for gaming but wanted to use it as a PC monitor as well so 1080p was important. Picture quality is excellent even from a side view, and built in speakers are adequate.  Quality for the price is excellent.

Reviews.Title: Great Tv With Amazing Picture Quality
Reviews.Author: BobbyRay
